subject: RE: [junit] A Growing Problem
messageBody:
> I was thinking more along the lines of a weekly build type of
> process, where everyone puts their updated code into a central
> location and the buildmaster compiles and tests everything.
> I can easily envision a case where someone either forgets to
> test their code or checks in the wrong code.

I can understand the frustration of builing the application once a week and
seeing that it's not working. But isn't it possible to build the application
once a day, or make a partial build (e.g. for one platform)? If your system is
complex, try to isolate the application to test. For example, if your working
with CORBA, don't test the corba bridge (your tests acting like a CORBA client)
but test your CORBA interface (your tests acting like a CORBA bridge). You'll
be able to test your CORBA code without starting a server.

If someone forgets to test their code or checks in the wrong code... well
mistakes happen. But having 1 (a) or 100 (b) errors while running your tests
tells you exactly the same thing: you have bugs in your code. Not to forget
that (a) is the same error as the first error of (b).

> everyone was testing their code multiple times a day and builds were a
> daily occurrence, but some of us are in traditional with the "fragile"
> way of doing things and are doing the best we can ;-)

so fix it! :-) Set up a dedicated build server and install a tool to check out
your code every day from CVS, compile it, execute the tests and report the
errors (like continuous integration on SF).

good luck

-Vladimir
